title: CRM Stock: Is It A Buy Right Now? Here's What Earnings, Salesforce Stock Chart Show
summary:
When mulling whether to buy CRM stock, consider two trends: higher corporate spending on digital transformation projects and Salesforce.com's (CRM) penchant to make big acquisitions.
In 2019, CRM stock lagged many high-growth enterprise software stocks as well as the oft-watched iShares Expanded Tech-Software ETF.
CRM stock had been-range bound for the better part of 15 months before breaking out to a new all-time high in early 2020.
CRM Stock: Technical AnalysisAccording to IBD Stock Checkup, CRM stock currently has a Relative Strength Rating of 85 out of a possible 99.
CRM stock has retreated and now trades in a buy zone above the 164.41 entry point.
text:
When mulling whether to buy CRM stock, consider two trends: higher corporate spending on digital transformation projects and Salesforce.com's (CRM) penchant to make big acquisitions. And, there's the ongoing coronavirus pandemic to mull and its impact on corporate spending.

X

Salesforce stock reports first-quarter earnings on May 28. The company will likely update guidance for CRM stock in the wake of Covid-19.

The bar keeps rising when investors look at Salesforce's "biggest acquisition ever." Its purchase of Exact Target in 2013 was followed by e-commerce platform Demandware in 2016, MuleSoft in 2018 and finally the $15.7 billion all-stock deal to buy data analytics firm Tableau Software (DATA) last year.

The acquisition spree has pressured CRM stock. The deals raised questions over Salesforce's organic growth.

In 2019, CRM stock lagged many high-growth enterprise software stocks as well as the oft-watched iShares Expanded Tech-Software ETF. CRM stock had been-range bound for the better part of 15 months before breaking out to a new all-time high in early 2020.

CRM Stock: Coronavirus Stokes Global Recession

The upbeat view is that acquisitions have enabled Salesforce to expand from its roots in customer relationship management software into marketing, e-commerce and application development. It's a leader in software-as-a-service (SaaS).

Bullish analysts say Salesforce stock is positioned well as companies increase spending on digital transformation projects. The projects turn paperwork into electronic records and automate business workflows. More companies aim to gain a competitive edge with business analytics/artificial intelligence tools that scrub customer data.

Meanwhile, the Coronavirus-driven bear market has pummeled many software stocks, despite stellar revenue growth. CRM stock may be in better shape than many software companies as a recession looms, says Jefferies analyst J. Derrick Wood.

"CRM is one of the few pure-play SaaS vendors to have gone through a recession," Wood said in a recent report to clients. "While organic revenue growth could get cut in over half in a recession, our free cash flow estimate could actually increase by several hundred million vs. our $5.6 billion estimate today. This is because, like we saw in the last cycle, margin expansion accelerates with a slowdown in growth investments. Importantly, this provides some fairly compelling earnings and valuation protection."

CRM Stock Fundamental Analysis

Salesforce is one of many big-cap tech stocks to watch. Started in 1999, Salesforce went public in 2004. Salesforce founder and Co-Chief Executive Marc Benioff worked at Oracle (ORCL) for 13 years before he left to start the software company.

In a surprise, co-CEO Keith Block on Feb. 25 stepped down. CRM stock fell on the news. Block had been viewed as a possible successor to Benioff.

Salesforce has been a fierce rival of Oracle and Microsoft (MSFT). Competition with Adobe Systems (ADBE), the digital media and marketing software firm, has been rising. Newer rivals include Zendesk (ZEN) and HubSpot (HUBS).

Salesforce software helps businesses organize and handle sales operations and customer relationships as they undergo digital transformation.

San Francisco-based Salesforce sells software under a subscription model. The customers of software-as-a-service, or SaaS, companies like Salesforce purchase renewable subscriptions, rather than one-time software licenses. Customers receive automatic software updates via the web.

CRM Stock: Core Business Strength An Issue

Salesforce on Feb. 25 reported fourth-quarter adjusted earnings of 66 cents a share, including a 3-cent investment gain, down 6% from a year earlier. Revenue climbed 35% to $4.85 billion, including the acquisition of Tableau Software.

Analysts expected Salesforce to report earnings of 56 cents on sales of $4.75 billion for the period ended Jan. 31.

The enterprise software maker said current remaining performance obligations, or CRPO bookings, rose 26% to $15 billion. That topped analysts estimate of 21% growth to $14.41 billion. CRPO bookings are an aggregate of deferred revenue and order backlog.

Before the Tableau acquisition, Salesforce had set a goal of $20 billion in annual revenue by 2022.

The company is spending 14% of revenue on research and development, relatively high for a software company. Increased hiring and wage inflation for software engineers also have been a headwind to margin growth.

Also, Microsoft, Oracle and SAP are still much bigger than Salesforce.

Salesforce Is One Artificial Intelligence Stock To Watch

One technology that Salesforce hopes will drive more revenue is artificial intelligence. The enterprise software maker introduced its "Einstein" AI software cloud platform in September 2016. The first Einstein AI software tools helped salespeople predict which deals are most likely to close based on a company's historical lead and account data.

Salesforce has integrated AI tools into other enterprise software offerings over the past three years, targeting industries such as financial services in digital transformation. Einstein AI primarily works via chat bots. While the Einstein AI software interests customers, it has yet to move the needle on revenue growth.

CRM Stock News

Salesforce in June agreed to buy data analytics firm Tableau for $15.7 billion in an all-stock deal. Tableau provides data visualization software. In addition, it enables customers to build databases, graphs and maps using time series analytics, a technique that analyzes a series of data points ordered in time.

Salesforce expects synergy between its Einstein artificial intelligence tools and Tableau's business intelligence software.

In 2018, Salesforce bought MuleSoft for $6.5 billion in cash and stock. MuleSoft's software automates the integration of new tools with legacy enterprise platforms and speeds application development.

Salesforce spent $4.6 billion on acquisitions in 2016. They included e-commerce platform Demandware. Furthermore, Salesforce's $2.5 billion purchase of Exact Target in 2013 jump-started its move into marketing software.

Bullish analysts say Salesforce AI's tools, plus Tableau, plus MuleSoft will make a powerful combination for digital transformation projects.

Salesforce aims to partner with IT services firms such as Accenture (ACN) to add customers. Despite U.S.-China trade tensions, Salesforce in July added Alibaba Group Holdings (BABA) as a sales channel partner in China.

In cloud computing, Salesforce has partnered with Google for data analytics. In addition, Salesforce has expanded its venture capital investing. It holds stakes in Zoom Video Communications (ZM) and other companies.

CRM Stock: Technical Analysis

According to IBD Stock Checkup, CRM stock currently has a Relative Strength Rating of 85 out of a possible 99. That means it has outperformed 85% of all other issues. The best stocks tend to have an RS rating of 80 or better.

Its relative strength line, which tracks a stock's performance vs. the S&P 500 index, had strengthened before the coronavirus-driven market correction.

CRM stock, meanwhile, has an Accumulation/Distribution Rating of C. It analyzes price and volume changes in a stock over the past 13 weeks of trading. The rating, on an A+ to E scale, measures institutional buying and selling in a stock. A+ signifies heavy institutional buying; E means heavy selling. Think of the C grade as neutral.

The IBD Computer-Software Enterprise group ranks No. 2 out of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. One view is that software stocks, especially those with healthy free cash flow like Salesforce, will outperform amid the coronavirus-driven market correction.

RingCentral (RNG) and ServiceNow (NOW) are among software stocks with the highest Composite Ratings in the group, according to IBD Stock Checkup. Growth stock investors generally should focus on the best stocks in leading industry groups.

Is Salesforce Stock A Buy?

CRM stock hit an all-time high of 193.36 on Feb. 20.Salesforce stock took a big hit like other software companies as Covid-19 spread globally. Shares hit an intra-day low of 115.29 on March 18, a correction of roughly 40%.

CRM stock rebounded. It forged a new, cup-with-handle entry point of 164.41. Salesforce stock climbed to a post-corona outbreak high of 183.30 on May 11.

CRM stock has retreated and now trades in a buy zone above the 164.41 entry point. The stock market has pulled back, with the Nasdaq and other major indexes trying to find support. It may be prudent to stay on the sidelines in the case of CRM stock. The company will likely discuss the impact of Covid-19 when it reports its first-quarter earnings on May 28.

Follow Reinhardt Krause on Twitter @reinhardtk_tech for updates on artificial intelligence, cybersecurity and 5G wireless.

      Is Salesforce Stock A Buy? Coronavirus Recession Slows Digital Transformation

      Licensing
      • REINHARDT KRAUSE
      • 08:00 AM ET 05/15/2020

      When mulling whether to buy CRM stock, consider two trends: higher corporate spending on digital transformation projects and Salesforce.com's (CRM) penchant to make big acquisitions. And, there's the ongoing coronavirus pandemic to mull and its impact on corporate spending.
